The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This move has the potential to drive innovation in healthcare, drug discovery, and economic diversification. The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. Abu Dhabiâ€™s initiative to commercialize its genetic database is a bold step that could position the UAE as a leader in biotech and precision medicine. This move has the potential to drive innovation in healthcare, drug discovery, and economic diversification. However, as with any pioneering effort, careful consideration is needed to ensure ethical safeguards, data privacy, and responsible governance. The Gulf region, including Kuwait, can learn from this approach, ensuring that genetic data is leveraged for scientific and economic advancement while maintaining public trust and regulatory integrity.

The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

Those night markets, the unimaginable discounts on everything, that philanthropy and thousands of people gathering everyday for their Iftar at every Mosque. I had privilege of having attended many high quality Iftar parties and believe me what differentiated them was the principle of equality.Wishing all of you a very happy & blessed EID. May Allah bless all!!!

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

Gulf Consulting Market: 2025 Update and Implications for R Consultancy GroupThe Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) consulting market has demonstrated robust growth, expanding by 13.2% in 2023 to reach $5.4 billion. This upward trajectory continued in 2024, with the market projected to hit approximately $8 billion by the end of 2025. Saudi Arabia remains a pivotal contributor, with its consulting sector growing by 14.1% in 2024 to $4.3 billion. â€‹Evolving Market DynamicsDespite this growth, the consulting landscape is experiencing shifts. Saudi Arabia is reassessing its expenditure on external consultants, leading to increased scrutiny and a demand for demonstrable value. This necessitates a focus on specialized expertise and tangible outcomes.â€‹Strategic Opportunities for R Consultancy GroupThese developments present strategic opportunities for R Consultancy Group (RCG):â€‹Specialized Expertise: RCG's deep understanding of the GCC market positions it to offer tailored solutions that address the region's unique challenges.â€‹By focusing on delivering measurable results, RCG can meet the heightened expectations of clients seeking clear returns on their investments.â€‹Staying abreast of market trends enables RCG to anticipate client needs and offer proactive solutions, reinforcing its role as a trusted advisor.â€‹In summary, while the GCC consulting market continues to grow, firms must adapt to evolving client expectations. This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. This move has the potential to drive innovation in healthcare, drug discovery, and economic diversification. However, as with any pioneering effort, careful consideration is needed to ensure ethical safeguards, data privacy, and responsible governance. The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. This move has the potential to drive innovation in healthcare, drug discovery, and economic diversification. However, as with any pioneering effort, careful consideration is needed to ensure ethical safeguards, data privacy, and responsible governance. The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

If you have a keen interest in feeling what the EID means, you should visit Dubai, a city of dreams, a city of perusing your dreams, a city that can transform your dreams into reality. The exchanges of gifts, the vibes of a festival, Iftar parties, the devotion to Almighty, all make them special. Whenever, Ramadan comes, my wife and me always remember Dubai. Those night markets, the unimaginable discounts on everything, that philanthropy and thousands of people gathering everyday for their Iftar at every Mosque. You will find people distributing snacks on every crossroads during Ramadan. Many a times, I brought such snacks and we had it together in the evening. I had privilege of having attended many high quality Iftar parties and believe me what differentiated them was the principle of equality.Wishing all of you a very happy & blessed EID. May Allah bless all!!!

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

Gulf Consulting Market: 2025 Update and Implications for R Consultancy GroupThe Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) consulting market has demonstrated robust growth, expanding by 13.2% in 2023 to reach $5.4 billion. This upward trajectory continued in 2024, with the market projected to hit approximately $8 billion by the end of 2025. Saudi Arabia remains a pivotal contributor, with its consulting sector growing by 14.1% in 2024 to $4.3 billion. â€‹Evolving Market DynamicsDespite this growth, the consulting landscape is experiencing shifts. Saudi Arabia is reassessing its expenditure on external consultants, leading to increased scrutiny and a demand for demonstrable value. This necessitates a focus on specialized expertise and tangible outcomes.â€‹Strategic Opportunities for R Consultancy GroupThese developments present strategic opportunities for R Consultancy Group (RCG):â€‹Specialized Expertise: RCG's deep understanding of the GCC market positions it to offer tailored solutions that address the region's unique challenges.â€‹By focusing on delivering measurable results, RCG can meet the heightened expectations of clients seeking clear returns on their investments.â€‹Staying abreast of market trends enables RCG to anticipate client needs and offer proactive solutions, reinforcing its role as a trusted advisor.â€‹In summary, while the GCC consulting market continues to grow, firms must adapt to evolving client expectations. This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. Abu Dhabiâ€™s initiative to commercialize its genetic database is a bold step that could position the UAE as a leader in biotech and precision medicine. This move has the potential to drive innovation in healthcare, drug discovery, and economic diversification. However, as with any pioneering effort, careful consideration is needed to ensure ethical safeguards, data privacy, and responsible governance. The Gulf region, including Kuwait, can learn from this approach, ensuring that genetic data is leveraged for scientific and economic advancement while maintaining public trust and regulatory integrity.

The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

Those night markets, the unimaginable discounts on everything, that philanthropy and thousands of people gathering everyday for their Iftar at every Mosque. I had privilege of having attended many high quality Iftar parties and believe me what differentiated them was the principle of equality.Wishing all of you a very happy & blessed EID. May Allah bless all!!!

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

Gulf Consulting Market: 2025 Update and Implications for R Consultancy GroupThe Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) consulting market has demonstrated robust growth, expanding by 13.2% in 2023 to reach $5.4 billion. This upward trajectory continued in 2024, with the market projected to hit approximately $8 billion by the end of 2025. Saudi Arabia remains a pivotal contributor, with its consulting sector growing by 14.1% in 2024 to $4.3 billion. â€‹Evolving Market DynamicsDespite this growth, the consulting landscape is experiencing shifts. Saudi Arabia is reassessing its expenditure on external consultants, leading to increased scrutiny and a demand for demonstrable value. This necessitates a focus on specialized expertise and tangible outcomes.â€‹Strategic Opportunities for R Consultancy GroupThese developments present strategic opportunities for R Consultancy Group (RCG):â€‹Specialized Expertise: RCG's deep understanding of the GCC market positions it to offer tailored solutions that address the region's unique challenges.â€‹By focusing on delivering measurable results, RCG can meet the heightened expectations of clients seeking clear returns on their investments.â€‹Staying abreast of market trends enables RCG to anticipate client needs and offer proactive solutions, reinforcing its role as a trusted advisor.â€‹In summary, while the GCC consulting market continues to grow, firms must adapt to evolving client expectations. This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This upward trajectory continued in 2024, with the market projected to hit approximately $8 billion by the end of 2025. Saudi Arabia remains a pivotal contributor, with its consulting sector growing by 14.1% in 2024 to $4.3 billion. â€‹Evolving Market DynamicsDespite this growth, the consulting landscape is experiencing shifts. Saudi Arabia is reassessing its expenditure on external consultants, leading to increased scrutiny and a demand for demonstrable value. This necessitates a focus on specialized expertise and tangible outcomes.â€‹Strategic Opportunities for R Consultancy GroupThese developments present strategic opportunities for R Consultancy Group (RCG):â€‹Specialized Expertise: RCG's deep understanding of the GCC market positions it to offer tailored solutions that address the region's unique challenges.â€‹By focusing on delivering measurable results, RCG can meet the heightened expectations of clients seeking clear returns on their investments.â€‹Staying abreast of market trends enables RCG to anticipate client needs and offer proactive solutions, reinforcing its role as a trusted advisor.â€‹In summary, while the GCC consulting market continues to grow, firms must adapt to evolving client expectations. This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. hashtag#Eid_holiday - Top Free Places to Visit in DubaiDubai offers plenty of incredible attractions that you can explore without spending a dirham on entry fees. Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the worldâ€™s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM â€“ 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. Al Fahidi Historical District (Bur Dubai)Explore Dubaiâ€™s past through old wind-tower houses, museums, and art galleries.6. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the worldâ€™s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Dubai Water Canal BoardwalkA picturesque walkway with a colorful waterfall bridge and skyline views.13. City Walk (Downtown Dubai)A stylish urban district with free street art and futuristic architecture.14. Quranic Park (Al Khawaneej)A peaceful park with Quran-inspired gardens and exhibits.15. Kite Beach (Jumeirah)A public beach great for swimming, jogging, and watching kitesurfers.16. Gold & Spice Souks (Deira)Explore traditional markets with dazzling jewelry and aromatic spices.17. The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. hashtag#Eid_holiday - Top Free Places to Visit in DubaiDubai offers plenty of incredible attractions that you can explore without spending a dirham on entry fees. Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the worldâ€™s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM â€“ 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. La Mer Beach (Jumeirah 1)A lively beachfront with stunning views, street art, and a relaxed atmosphere.4. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. Al Fahidi Historical District (Bur Dubai)Explore Dubaiâ€™s past through old wind-tower houses, museums, and art galleries.6. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the worldâ€™s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Love Lake Dubai (Al Qudra)A heart-shaped lake surrounded by nature, ideal for a peaceful escape.9. Dubai Marina WalkA 7-km scenic walkway lined with skyscrapers, cafes, and nightlife spots.10. Bur Dubai Grand MosqueA beautiful mosque offering free cultural tours for non-Muslims.11. Hatta DamA stunning mountain landscape with crystal-clear waters, perfect for photography.12. Dubai Water Canal BoardwalkA picturesque walkway with a colorful waterfall bridge and skyline views.13. City Walk (Downtown Dubai)A stylish urban district with free street art and futuristic architecture.14. Quranic Park (Al Khawaneej)A peaceful park with Quran-inspired gardens and exhibits.15. Kite Beach (Jumeirah)A public beach great for swimming, jogging, and watching kitesurfers.16. Gold & Spice Souks (Deira)Explore traditional markets with dazzling jewelry and aromatic spices.17. Dubai Mall & Aquarium (Outside View)Enjoy free views of the massive Dubai Aquarium inside The Dubai Mall.Dubai has plenty of amazing free experiencesâ€”which one will you visit first?hashtag#Eid hashtag#holidays hashtag#Dubai hashtag#free hashtag#dubaimall hashtag#burjkhalifa hashtag#goldsouk hashtag#aquarium hashtag#Kitebeach hashtag#citywalk hashtag#Hatta hashtag#watercanal hashtag#Marina hashtag#lovelake hashtag#JBR hashtag#La_mer hashtag#beach hashtag#Dubaifountainshow

The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric faÃ§ade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. For more details on GDP performance, kindly refer to the attached link below.hashtag#EconomicRecoveryhashtag#GDPGrowth hashtag#EconomicDevelopment hashtag#ManufacturingSector hashtag#FiscalPerformance

hashtag#Eid_holiday - Top Free Places to Visit in DubaiDubai offers plenty of incredible attractions that you can explore without spending a dirham on entry fees. Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the worldâ€™s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM â€“ 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. La Mer Beach (Jumeirah 1)A lively beachfront with stunning views, street art, and a relaxed atmosphere.4. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. Al Fahidi Historical District (Bur Dubai)Explore Dubaiâ€™s past through old wind-tower houses, museums, and art galleries.6. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the worldâ€™s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Love Lake Dubai (Al Qudra)A heart-shaped lake surrounded by nature, ideal for a peaceful escape.9. Dubai Marina WalkA 7-km scenic walkway lined with skyscrapers, cafes, and nightlife spots.10. Bur Dubai Grand MosqueA beautiful mosque offering free cultural tours for non-Muslims.11. Hatta DamA stunning mountain landscape with crystal-clear waters, perfect for photography.12. Dubai Water Canal BoardwalkA picturesque walkway with a colorful waterfall bridge and skyline views.13. City Walk (Downtown Dubai)A stylish urban district with free street art and futuristic architecture.14. Quranic Park (Al Khawaneej)A peaceful park with Quran-inspired gardens and exhibits.15. Kite Beach (Jumeirah)A public beach great for swimming, jogging, and watching kitesurfers.16. Gold & Spice Souks (Deira)Explore traditional markets with dazzling jewelry and aromatic spices.17. Dubai Mall & Aquarium (Outside View)Enjoy free views of the massive Dubai Aquarium inside The Dubai Mall.Dubai has plenty of amazing free experiencesâ€”which one will you visit first?hashtag#Eid hashtag#holidays hashtag#Dubai hashtag#free hashtag#dubaimall hashtag#burjkhalifa hashtag#goldsouk hashtag#aquarium hashtag#Kitebeach hashtag#citywalk hashtag#Hatta hashtag#watercanal hashtag#Marina hashtag#lovelake hashtag#JBR hashtag#La_mer hashtag#beach hashtag#Dubaifountainshow

The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric faÃ§ade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. ğŸ¯ His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. ğŸ¯ Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. ğŸ¯ It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. ğŸ‘‰ When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. Abu Dhabiâ€™s initiative to commercialize its genetic database is a bold step that could position the UAE as a leader in biotech and precision medicine. This move has the potential to drive innovation in healthcare, drug discovery, and economic diversification. However, as with any pioneering effort, careful consideration is needed to ensure ethical safeguards, data privacy, and responsible governance. The Gulf region, including Kuwait, can learn from this approach, ensuring that genetic data is leveraged for scientific and economic advancement while maintaining public trust and regulatory integrity.

The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

If you have a keen interest in feeling what the EID means, you should visit Dubai, a city of dreams, a city of perusing your dreams, a city that can transform your dreams into reality. The exchanges of gifts, the vibes of a festival, Iftar parties, the devotion to Almighty, all make them special. Whenever, Ramadan comes, my wife and me always remember Dubai. Those night markets, the unimaginable discounts on everything, that philanthropy and thousands of people gathering everyday for their Iftar at every Mosque. You will find people distributing snacks on every crossroads during Ramadan. Many a times, I brought such snacks and we had it together in the evening. I had privilege of having attended many high quality Iftar parties and believe me what differentiated them was the principle of equality.Wishing all of you a very happy & blessed EID. May Allah bless all!!!

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. hashtag#Eid_holiday - Top Free Places to Visit in DubaiDubai offers plenty of incredible attractions that you can explore without spending a dirham on entry fees. Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the worldâ€™s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM â€“ 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. La Mer Beach (Jumeirah 1)A lively beachfront with stunning views, street art, and a relaxed atmosphere.4. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. Al Fahidi Historical District (Bur Dubai)Explore Dubaiâ€™s past through old wind-tower houses, museums, and art galleries.6. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the worldâ€™s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Love Lake Dubai (Al Qudra)A heart-shaped lake surrounded by nature, ideal for a peaceful escape.9. Dubai Marina WalkA 7-km scenic walkway lined with skyscrapers, cafes, and nightlife spots.10. Bur Dubai Grand MosqueA beautiful mosque offering free cultural tours for non-Muslims.11. Hatta DamA stunning mountain landscape with crystal-clear waters, perfect for photography.12. Dubai Water Canal BoardwalkA picturesque walkway with a colorful waterfall bridge and skyline views.13. City Walk (Downtown Dubai)A stylish urban district with free street art and futuristic architecture.14. Quranic Park (Al Khawaneej)A peaceful park with Quran-inspired gardens and exhibits.15. Kite Beach (Jumeirah)A public beach great for swimming, jogging, and watching kitesurfers.16. Gold & Spice Souks (Deira)Explore traditional markets with dazzling jewelry and aromatic spices.17. The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric faÃ§ade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. ğŸ¯ His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. ğŸ¯ Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. ğŸ¯ It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. ğŸ‘‰ When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. This move has the potential to drive innovation in healthcare, drug discovery, and economic diversification. However, as with any pioneering effort, careful consideration is needed to ensure ethical safeguards, data privacy, and responsible governance. The UAEâ€™s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patienceâ€”the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the futureâ€”not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sectorâ€™s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric faÃ§ade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. ğŸ¯ His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. ğŸ¯ Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. ğŸ¯ It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. ğŸ‘‰ When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. This move has the potential to drive innovation in healthcare, drug discovery, and economic diversification. However, as with any pioneering effort, careful consideration is needed to ensure ethical safeguards, data privacy, and responsible governance.
